SENT.plain: Benign epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes (BECTS) is associated with language disturbances during the active phase of the seizure disorder
However, it is not yet known whether these deficits are reversible or have long-term impact on the development of language skills
We report on a study conducted in 13 patients in remission from BECTS and 13 age-matched controls, who underwent neuropsychological assessments
We also recorded event-related potentials (ERPs) during a verb generation task, to determine cortical lateralization of language
The BECTS group showed significant language deficits compared to controls as well as a pattern of atypical ERP lateralization in frontal regions
These findings support the view that BECTS in childhood may lead to enduring effects on brain maturation and language development
